intro: Heracleum pyrenaicum var. setosum, commonly known as the hairy cow parsnip, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, characterized by its compound leaves and umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, disturbed habitats such as meadows and riverbanks. It produces a tall stem with a hollow, ridged appearance and bears small, yellowish-green flowers in umbrella-like clusters. The leaves are broad, heart-shaped, and covered in fine, hairy textures, contributing to its distinctive appearance.
